Black hair coat is dominant over white hair coat. Three quarters of the offspring have black coats, and one quarter have white coats. The genotypes of the parents were most likely

A. Bb × Bb

B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

C. bb × Bb

D. bb × bb

E. bb × BB

F. Bb × bb

G. Bb × BB

H. BB × Bb

I. BB × bb

J. BB × BB

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white). That matches the given ratio exactly. So F is a possibility. Looking further, let's check other options. G is Bb × BB. As above, BB gives B, so all offspring would be B_, meaning all B_ (like Bb or BB). They would all be black, except if someone else is involved, but in this case, it's just Bb × BB. So all offspring would be B_, which is black. So G wouldn't fit because it results in all black, not matching the ¾ black ratio. H is BB × Bb. This is similar to option F; it's the same as Bb × bb. Both parents are contributing alleles, leading to a 50-50 chance of each. So same result as F—50% black, 50% white. Not matching the required ¾ black. I is BB × bb. Similar reasoning: BB gives B, bb gives b. All offspring would be B_, so all black. No white, so I is out. J is BB × BB. Both parents are BB, so all offspring are BB, hence all black. Doesn't fit.

Now, considering option F again: Bb × bb. Each parent contributes one allele. The bb parent will pass b, and the Bb parent can pass either B or b. So half the time, the offspring get B (from Bb) and b (from bb), making Bb (black). Half the time, they get b (from Bb) and b (from bb), making bb (white). So the ratio is 1:1, which corresponds to 75% black and 25% white. Perfect, that fits the given data. So the parents must be Bb and bb. Looking back at the answer choices, option F is Bb × bb.
</think>
The correct answer is F
